medical: HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient presents today for followup. No dysuria, gross hematuria, fever, chills. She continues to have urinary incontinence, especially while changing from sitting to standing position, as well as urge incontinence. She is voiding daytime every 1 hour in the morning especially after taking Lasix, which tapers off in the afternoon, nocturia time 0. No incontinence. No straining to urinate. Good stream, emptying well. No bowel issues, however, she also indicates that while using her vaginal cream, she has difficulty doing this as she feels protrusion in the vagina, and very concerned if she has a prolapse. IMPRESSION: 1. The patient noted for improving retention of urine, postop vaginal reconstruction, very concerned of possible vaginal prolapse, especially while using the cream. 2. Rule out ascites, with no GI issues other than lower extremity edema. PLAN: Following a detailed discussion with the patient, she elected to proceed with continued Flomax and will wean off the Urecholine to two times daily. She will follow up next week, request Dr. X to do a pelvic exam, and in the meantime, she will obtain a CT of the abdomen and pelvis to further evaluate the cause of the abdominal distention. All questions answered.
layman:
**History of Present Illness:**  
The patient came in for a followâ€‘up visit. She reports no pain when urinating, no visible blood in the urine, and no fever or chills. She still has urinary incontinence, especially when she moves from sitting to standing, and she also has urge incontinence. She is urinating every hour during the day, especially after taking Lasix, which lessens in the afternoon. She does not have nighttime urination or incontinence. She does not strain to urinate, has a good stream, and feels she empties her bladder well. She has no bowel problems. However, she says that when she uses her vaginal cream, she feels a protrusion in her vagina and is worried it might be a prolapse.

**Impression:**  
1. The patient is improving in holding urine after her vaginal reconstruction surgery, but she is concerned about a possible vaginal prolapse, especially when using the cream.  
2. We need to rule out ascites; she has no gastrointestinal symptoms other than swelling in her legs.

**Plan:**  
After a detailed discussion, the patient decided to keep taking Flomax and to reduce Urecholine to twice a day. She will return next week, ask Dr. X to perform a pelvic exam, and in the meantime will get a CT scan of her abdomen and pelvis to investigate the abdominal swelling. All her questions were answered.
